summary: A letter from Manleys Solicitors to Judge Alison J. Nathan requesting redaction of their client's name (a former PA to Ghislaine Maxwell) from court papers in Maxwell's upcoming criminal trial. The letter details previous inadequate redactions in defamation proceedings that led to media exposure of their client, who is a victim of sexual crimes and entitled to anonymity under UK law.

keyFacts: The client is a former personal assistant to Ghislaine Maxwell and a victim of sexual crimes who has reported them to the Metropolitan Police in London.
Under UK law (Sexual Offences (Amendment) Act 1992), the client has a lifelong entitlement to anonymity as a victim of sexual crimes.
Previous redaction efforts in defamation proceedings were inadequate, leading to the client's name being published in British media, causing distress.
Manleys Solicitors successfully threatened British media with contempt proceedings to remove publications identifying their client.
The letter requests assurances that all documents, including those from previous proceedings, will have the client's name and any variations properly redacted.
